instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A w/liquid damage, magsafe responds but no power?
threads.message:
Liquid damage pretty extensively on the I/O board, but the main logic board was mostly untouched--only slight corrosion around <CHIP>U7330</CHIP>, nothing on backside.
Cleaned her up, no change in magsafe (goes green, then amber), fans do not whir. All main power rails are there, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> are virtually not there, at .001 or 0.0mv. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD</SIGNAL> is also missing, as you could guess, 0.0v.
Diode mode shows .286v for <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, .388v for <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>, so no shorts on those lines I think. Not sure where they are created, that'd be my next path.
Would <TRANSISTOR>Q8131</TRANSISTOR> be suspect? I'm getting a healthy 3.3/3.4v on <SIGNAL>CHGR_VFRQ</SIGNAL> but nothing coming out of pin 1, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL>. I think that because <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>, the 'S0 enable' chip, has a healthy 3.3v on pin 5, but absolutely nothing on the other pins, including <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A w/liquid damage, magsafe responds but no power?
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
Also post exact voltage for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Are you using original 85W Magsafe 2 charger?
Try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A w/liquid damage, magsafe responds but no power?
threads.message:
3.388 - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>
3.347 - <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>
3.383 - <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
3.417 - <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
3.229 - <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>
3.349 - <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
3.351 - <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>

12.57 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, you think this one is a little low? Know it's supposed to be 12.8 but didn't seem too far off.
Using OG charger, not a knockoff. I'll report back with SMC bypass.

edit - no luck with SMC bypass. :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A w/liquid damage, magsafe responds but no power?
threads.message:
MLB should start without RIO board connected.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal and check for any reaction at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
Also check if any of <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals react; one pulse at least.
Monitor <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A w/liquid damage, magsafe responds but no power?
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> responds--reoccurring pulses as long as <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is bridged.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> responds--one pulse when bridging. I'm assuming the others do too.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> response, same as <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL>--one pulse when bridging. What does this mean... :()

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A w/liquid damage, magsafe responds but no power?
threads.message:
Then you must get pulse at the big coils too; maybe not for CPU.
Check if any coil has no reaction at all.
Look at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> for corrosion.
See if pins 7 & 3 react too.
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_SB</SIGNAL> tries to appear?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A w/liquid damage, magsafe responds but no power?
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> looks fine, pins 7 & 3 along with <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_SB</SIGNAL> pulse with bridging <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
All the coils devoid of signals to begin with pulse when bridging except for one--L3095. You can see if I'm missing any, I tested these:
L7520
L7430
L7870
L7310/20/30

L7130, 7560 and L7630 all have signals before bridging, w/7130 having 12.57 and 7560 3.3. L7630 has a signal, but it's a very weak 2.5mv, probably a short on <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>? Not sure.
edit - diode mode shows .090v on L7630, definitely sounds like a short right? Maybe not, other boards test around .07v diode mode there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A w/liquid damage, magsafe responds but no power?
threads.message: Liquid near <CHIP>U7330</CHIP> is no bueno this sounds like a dead CPU..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A w/liquid damage, magsafe responds but no power?
threads.message:
Don't say that John :( if that was the case, wouldn't the <SIGNAL>CPU_PHASE</SIGNAL> coils not be pulsing when I bridge <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>? Also all the main power rails for ISNS are alive and well.

edit - if it's important info, when plugging in the charger <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> aren't immediately at 0.0v, they rapidly descend from a relatively small voltage and settle at 0.0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A w/liquid damage, magsafe responds but no power?
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_SB</SIGNAL> should be check with o-scope, or frequency meter; there must be 25MHz oscillation.

L7630 must also pulse with all other coils, when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered.

Try new BIOS file.
